meta.title: People (Kukai / Kobo Daishi)
meta.description: Cards that translate understanding of people into learning and action rather than veneration.

cards.title: Kukai: known as the founder of Japanese Shingon esoteric Buddhism
cards.summary: The SEP describes Kukai as widely known for founding Shingon esoteric Buddhism in Japan.
cards.body_md:
The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (SEP) entry on Kukai notes that Kukai (774-835) is widely known as the founder of Shingon esoteric Buddhism in Japan.

In this app, we translate reverence into daily alignment: practice body, speech, and mind.

micro_practice.morning: Decide on just one learning for today (do not overreach).
micro_practice.night: Record today's practice in one line.

reflection_questions: If you translate a great person's life into today's actions, what would that be?

cards.title: Kobo Daishi: an honorific title for Kukai
cards.summary: This app keeps naming consistent to reduce confusion.
cards.body_md:
Academic overviews (SEP) often use the name Kukai.

In the app, we mention Kukai (Kobo Daishi) once, then treat them as the same person to avoid confusion.

micro_practice.morning: Hold the equivalence in mind: Kukai = Kobo Daishi.
micro_practice.day: Open the glossary when an unfamiliar term appears (don't leave it vague).
micro_practice.night: Write down one term you encountered today.

reflection_questions: What word confused you today? How would you rephrase it in one line?

cards.title: Understanding Kukai: build a circuit of practice, not just knowledge
cards.summary: Make the Three Mysteries (body, speech, mind) a daily circuit.
cards.body_md:
The official Koyasan Shingon explanation describes Sanmitsu Kaji (Sanmitsu Yoga), notes that body, speech, and mind mutually respond, and mentions nyuga ganyu.

Understanding a person connects to running that circuit (body, speech, mind) in everyday life.

micro_practice.morning: First body (posture) -> then speech (careful words) -> finally mind (today's focus).
micro_practice.day: When you are disturbed, return in order: body -> speech -> mind.
micro_practice.night: Choose and record which of body, speech, or mind felt most supportive today.

reflection_questions: Which felt most supportive today: body, speech, or mind?
If the same situation happens tomorrow, how will you order them?

cards.title: Toji: explains the idea of making the mandala three-dimensional
cards.summary: Toji (official) explains the mandala and the three-dimensional mandala (Karma Mandala).
cards.body_md:
Toji (official) explains that mandalas are a clear expression of esoteric teachings, that there are the Womb Realm Mandala and the Diamond Realm Mandala, and that the Karma Mandala (commonly called a three-dimensional mandala) embodies that concept.

In this app, learn the idea of moving from seeing to doing.

micro_practice.morning: Create a see -> do order: read, then do one thing.
micro_practice.day: When you notice, adjust posture once (movement).
micro_practice.night: Write one moment you aligned through action today.

reflection_questions: Did you stop at seeing today? Or did you move into doing?

cards.title: Koyasan: refer to official explanations as the baseline
cards.summary: Use official explanations as the baseline for this app.
cards.body_md:
The official Koyasan Shingon explanations cover esoteric and exoteric teachings, Sanmitsu Kaji, nyuga ganyu, Dharma Body Buddha, and more. They are a baseline for the app's core vocabulary.

When adding cards later, build sources in this order: official -> dictionary -> academic.

micro_practice.morning: Build the habit of checking sources for terms.
micro_practice.day: Avoid vague phrasing; return to definitions.
micro_practice.night: Open one source for a term you learned today.

cards.title: Translate respect into a daily step
cards.summary: Respect is good, but in this app we convert it to one action for today.
cards.body_md:
This is a practice card for the app's design.

Translate respect into one action today:
- Body: return to posture
- Speech: choose one careful word
- Mind: observe irritation

Not a doctrinal claim, but a behavioral design for the app.

micro_practice.night: Write one correction without blaming yourself.

reflection_questions: When did respect become action today?
